metadata.shortDescription: Learn web programming in Java by building your own online e-commerce application.
metadata.synopsis: In this course, you will develop an online e-commerce website and take it live using the Google App Engine cloud platform. You will learn advanced concepts in Java programming and technology frameworks to build such large scale e-commerce applications, take them live and test them under load of thousands of users.
metadata.description:
You will learn the complete stack from developing engaging user experiences, programming the business logic, storing and retrieving data in the database, and take your app live.

In college, you would have learnt programming, Java, data structures, algorithms etc. This course builds on that foundation to teach you the tools and technologies that you will encounter in your projects. By the end of this course, you will have acquired the skills to develop almost any kind of business application while working in large development teams.

You should have a good working knowledge of the Java programming language, HTML and JavaScript before taking this course.
metadata.homeDescription: In this course, you will develop an online e-commerce website and take it live using the Google App Engine cloud platform. You will learn advanced concepts in Java programming and technology frameworks to build such large scale e-commerce applications, take them live and test them under load of thousands of users.
metadata.objectives:
As you build your own online e-commerce website, you will gain a complete experience of building a real world app and this is valuable to the industry. The objectives of the course are:


  • Learn advanced Java programming
  • Learn open source frameworks like Spring and Hibernate
  • Familiarize with Cloud Computing and Google PaaS
  • Understand UI programming using JavaScript and jQuery
  • Learn to apply principles of OOAD and design patterns
  • Learn programming & development best practices
  • Learn to build scalable apps & measure performance
  • Learn the tools and processes used to develop real world software
metadata.projectDescription:
Your showcase project for this course is an online book store, where the users can browse for books, view details of the books and search for the books. Since this is a test project, we will not implement buying and shipping of books.

Your own book store will be LIVE. You can use it to showcase the expertise you have developed as part of this course. Your potential employers will appreciate if they can see the work you have done rather than some degrees and grades.

metadata.shortDescription: Familiarize yourself with the problem (online book store) and the tools that will be used in building.
metadata.synopsis: In this course, you will build your own online e-commerce application - a book store. You will use tools like Eclipse, Maven and Git as part of the development process. This module familiarizes you with the problem, and the tools that will be used.
metadata.description:
In this course, you will develop an online e-commerce website and take it live using the Google App Engine cloud platform. You will learn advanced concepts in Java programming and technology frameworks to build such large scale e-commerce applications, take them live and test them under load of thousands of users.

Your Showcase Project

This course is unlike most other courses, where you learn concepts and at the end and appear in an exam to earn a passing certificate. In this course, your learning is centered around a live showcase project that you will develop. While you will learn the real complexities in software development as you build the project, it will also be your showcase to demonstrate the skill and capability to potential employers.


The book store maintains a repository of books and various information related to the books such as authors, publishers, and the series of books. The users can browse the book repository and see the details, search for books on the book store and add them to their shopping cart. Anonymouse users can browse for books, but when they want to checkout, they must sign up into the book store before proceeding. Since this is only a showcase project, you will not actually integrate with a payment gateway.

The course is organized into a 5 main modules. Each module is about 1 week and you will build an incrementally rich system that is complete in itself to familiarize you with the iterative development process. There is additional tutoring videos available. There are quizzes and exercises as part of your lecture video, designed to measure your understanding as you progress through the lecture. Each lesson is backed by exercises and assignments that are graded towards your goal. If you get stuck, you can contact the tutors who will help you and explain the concepts if needed.

References

Books

  • The Pragmatic Programmer - by Dave Thomas and Andy Hunt
  • Code Complete - by Steve McConnel
  • Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software
  • Refactoring to Patterns - by Joshua Kerievsky

Blogs and Resources

  • Martin Fowler - (http://martinfowler.com) - Martin Fowler is one of the leading proponents of agile and evolutionary software design and development. His blog (he calls it Bliki) covers topics ranging from agile development, design patterns, refactoring and continuous integration which are very relevant to us.
  • Scott Ambler - (http://www.ambysoft.com/onlineWritings.html#Java) - Scott Ambler is an author, speaker and consultant. His blog includes writings on agile methodologies, Java design patterns, modeling etc and is a good resource to follow.

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Maven
metadata.description:
Maven 2.0 is based around the central concept of a build lifecycle. What this means is that the process for building and distributing a particular artifact (project) is clearly defined.

For the person building a project, this means that it is only necessary to learn a small set of commands to build any Maven project, and the POM will ensure they get the results they desired.

There are three built-in build lifecycles: default, clean and site. The default lifecycle handles your project deployment, the clean lifecycle handles project cleaning, while the site lifecycle handles the creation of your project's site documentation.

This quiz is based on the Maven build lifecycle and assesses your understanding of the build commands, phases and how Maven works.
metadata.synopsis: Before proceeding further, validate your understanding of Maven concepts as they will be required for the next lectures. If you are not confident or comfortable, please go through the turing lectures or contact your tutor.

metadata.shortDescription: Learn how to develop a simple web application and deploy on cloud.
metadata.synopsis: You will learn and develop your first web application and deploy it live on the Google App Engine. You will learn the process of software development, build, deploy cycle and learn how to create and deploy app on GAE.
metadata.description:
In this module, you will build your first web application and deploy it on Google App Engine - LIVE. The application we will develop is a simple Guestbook - and is available as a sample program from the Google App Engine. So there is not much of Java coding needed.

The module introduces you to the big picture without getting lost in Java coding. You will go through a complete process of how you start a project from scratch, build it, test it and take it live. You will learn the complete SDLC process including the role of tools like Maven in the process. This will give you a concrete idea of what the next 4 modules are going to focus on.

The module also introduces you to basic structure of a web app, how web apps are designed, deployed and executed. It introduces you to Cloud Computing and Google App Engine. As you build your first web application, you will deploy it in the cloud and take it live. This will give you a fairly good understanding of the complete process and working with Google App Engine in particular.

metadata.synopsis: This lecture introduces you to cloud computing and the basic ideas of scalability and the services offered by cloud environments. It explains various terms such as SaaS, PaaS and IaaS.
metadata.description: This lecture introduces you to Cloud Computing. The main challenge for applications is the scalability as the load on the application increases. Vertical scaling refers to putting bigger servers to cater to increasing load. Horizontal scaling refers to adding more servers (instead of one bigger server). Cloud computing provides a horizontal scalability model where the capacity available can be scaled on demand. Apart from scalability, cloud computing also offers several other key services such as cost advantage (in terms of pay-per-use) and self-service capabilities while hiding all operational challenges for running large scale software applications.

metadata.shortDescription: Introduction to Google Appengine and its various services.
metadata.synopsis: This lecture introduces you to Google app engine. Appengine is a PaaS service from Google and allows you to develop applications that leverage the Google computing platform along with other google services.
metadata.description:
Google App Engine is a Platform as a Service (PaaS) offering that lets you build and run applications on Google's infrastructure. App Engine applications are easy to build, easy to maintain, and easy to scale as your traffic and data storage needs change. With App Engine, there are no servers for you to maintain. You simply upload your application and it's ready to go.

Google App Engine makes it easy to build and deploy an application that runs reliably even under heavy load and with large amounts of data. It includes the following features:

  • Persistent storage with queries, sorting, and transactions.
  • Automatic scaling and load balancing.
  • Asynchronous task queues for performing work outside the scope of a request.
  • Scheduled tasks for triggering events at specified times or regular intervals.
  • Integration with other Google cloud services and APIs.

Applications run in a secure, sandboxed environment, allowing App Engine to distribute requests across multiple servers, and scaling servers to meet traffic demands. Your application runs within its own secure, reliable environment that is independent of the hardware, operating system, or physical location of the server.

metadata.synopsis: You will learn how to work with the google appengine SDK and use the devserver to run the application locally. The devserver provides an embedded data store and a web container. The SDK provides abstractions for other services.
metadata.description:
You will learn how to work with the devserver to test the application in your development environment before deploying it LIVE on the appengine. The devserver is part of the appengine SDK and allows you to run the application locally even as the rest of google infrastructure and services are not available.

Devserver provides an embedded web container service, and an embedded database for the application to run locally. The SDK provides mocks for other google services that the application may rely on, giving you a complete environment to test the application.

metadata.shortDescription: How does the devserver work locally and abstracts the various Google services.
metadata.synopsis: This lecture explains how the devserver works, and walks you through the project structure, where is the embedded data stored and how does it mock the other GAE services.
metadata.description:
Software Development Kits (SDKs) for App Engine are available in all supported languages. Each SDK includes:

  1. All of the APIs and libraries available to App Engine.
  2. A simulated, secure sandbox environment, that emulates all of the App Engine services on your local computer.
  3. Deployment tools that allow you to upload your application to the cloud and manage different versions of your application.

The SDK manages your application locally, while the Administration Console manages your application in production. The Administration Console uses a web-based interface to create new applications, configure domain names, change which version of your application is live, examine access and error logs, and much more.
metadata.keyword: Google Appengine: devserver,Google Appengine: appengine sdk

metadata.shortDescription: Deploy your application LIVE on google app engine and manage it on the console.
metadata.synopsis: This lesson takes you through the process of deploying your application on the Google appengine platform. Once the application is deployed, it is LIVE and anyone with the application URL can access the app.
metadata.description:
To deploy the application on the Google appengine platform, you simply have to run the mvn appengine:update command on the maven project. The SDK validates the build, runs the unit tests and deploys the application on the appengine infrastructure. For the first deployment, the SDK will require you to authenticate against the google accounts service and save an oauth token that is automatically used for subsequent deployments (so that you dont have to authenticate every time).

Once the application is updated, it is automatically taken live by the appengine infrastructure by allocating the necessary resources to it. Sometimes, the application indices may take a few mins to build - the application is not available till that period. Once all resources are ready to server, the application is live.

By the end of this lesson, you will deploy your own guestbook application on the appengine infrastructure and take it LIVE. Once live, you can access the appengine console to manage the application.

metadata.shortDescription: Deploy your application LIVE on google app engine.
metadata.synopsis: This lecture takes you through the step-by-step process of building and deploying your project on the appengine infrastructure. The steps explained include generating the oauth token and validating the deployment.
metadata.description:
To upload an app created with the the maven archetype:

Change directory to the top level of your project's EAR hierarchy (for example, myapp/myapp-ear) and invoke Maven as follows:

mvn appengine:update

You will be prompted for an authorization code in the terminal window and your web browser will launch with a consent screen which you must accept in order to be authorized. Follow the prompts to copy any codes from the browser to the command line.

metadata.shortDescription: Debug the application, view application logs and troubleshoot issues.
metadata.synopsis: When you deploy your application, you may see an error for a little while. This lecture walks you through the process of troubleshooting the application by looking at the logs in the console.
metadata.description:
When you deploy the application, you may see an error for a little while. This error is usually due to the index not being ready as it takes a little bit of time (a few minutes) for any new index to become ready to serve.

This lesson explains how to debug such issues by looking at the application logs in the appengine console. The logs will give you a clear explanation of the problem (in this case the index) and you can access the status of the index on the console to see. Any other runtime error encountered by the application can be debugged in the same way by accessing the logs in the console.

metadata.shortDescription: Manage the application using the appengine console.
metadata.synopsis: This lecture familiarizes you with the appengine console, so that you can manage the application and its deployment/runtime behavior yourself.
metadata.description:
The App Engine Admin Console gives you complete access to the public version of your application. Access the Console by visiting the following link in your web browser:

https://appengine.google.com/

If you are using App Engine with your Google Apps account, you can sign in to App Engine for your domain using a URL similar to the following, where your-domain.com is your Google Apps domain:

https://appengine.google.com/a/your-domain.com

You can use the Administration Console to manage various aspects of your application such as the number of instances of the application, datastore access, or manage the task queues. Administration console also allows you to monitor the load and performance of your application. You can see the number of requests on your application and the response time, throughput etc.

Learn how to store and query data from database using Hibernate and Java.
metadata.synopsis: You will develop the storage layer for the book store using Hibernate. You will understand Hibernate, ORM and how to map data between database tables and Java classes.
metadata.description:
You will take the books data and store it in the database using Hibernate and learn how to query it. You will build the data layer and understand the domain driven design and the repository design patterns.

The concepts you will learn include Hibernate, designing persistent entities, creating indices and querying and updating the data. You will learn how to write Junit test cases to validate the functionality. You will learn about factory design patterns, connection pooling and mocking unit tests.

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  JDBC,Java software programming:  ORM,Java software programming:  Database,Java Hibernate:  impedance mismatch
metadata.description:
This lesson introduces you to the JDBC API and how to access data from a Java application. It highlights the issues with the JDBC API and potential problems and explains how an object-relational mapping tool (ORM) addresses these issues.

JDBC API has sevaral issues related to code bloating, writing repetitive code and chances of making a mistake. The ORM tools simplify the code complexity and provide automatic mapping between relational model (tables) and object model (classes).
metadata.synopsis: This lesson introduces you to the JDBC API and how to access data from a Java application. It highlights the issues with the JDBC API and potential problems and explains how an object-relational mapping tool (ORM) addresses these issues.
metadata.shortDescription: Accessing databases from Java using JDBC API and the need for Object-Relational mapping tools.
Basics of the JDBC API and the pros and cons of using JDBC to access database from Java
metadata.synopsis: JDBC API has sevaral issues related to code bloating, writing repetitive code and chances of making a mistake. While it excels in terms of performance, the programming complexity needs to be addressed.
metadata.description:
JDBC API has sevaral issues related to code bloating, writing repetitive code and chances of making a mistake. While it excels in terms of performance, the programming complexity needs to be addressed.

JDBC API results in a lot of boilerplate code. For simple things such as firing a select query or updating data in the database, many lines of code is written. This bloats the program, makes it difficult to manage and leads to possibilities of making mistakes such as unclosed connections or incorrect transformation of JDBC data types.

metadata.programTemplate: Book b1 = new Book(1987, "Lord of the Rings", "Book 1", 800);Book b2 = new Book(2004, "Chronicles of Narnia", "LWW", 1350);Book b3 = new Book(2008, "Harry Potter v1", "V1", 400);Book b4 = new Book(1890, "Tale of Two Cities", "B1", 605);List books = new ArrayList();books.add(b1);books.add(b2);books.add(b3);books.add(b4);// Insert the code to print the books in reverse sorted order// ???// Expected Output: [1890, 1987, 2004, 2008]
metadata.programAnswer: Book b1 = new Book(1987, "Lord of the Rings", "Book 1", 800);Book b2 = new Book(2004, "Chronicles of Narnia", "LWW", 1350);Book b3 = new Book(2008, "Harry Potter v1", "V1", 400);Book b4 = new Book(1890, "Tale of Two Cities", "B1", 605);List books = new ArrayList();books.add(b1);books.add(b2);books.add(b3);books.add(b4);// Insert the code to print the books in reverse sorted orderComparator cmp = Collections.reverseOrder(new YearComparator());Collections.sort(books, cmp);// Expected Output: [1890, 1987, 2004, 2008]

metadata.synopsis: This lecture introduces you to Spring Framework. Spring framework is a lightweight container that implements the Dependency Injection design pattern.
metadata.description: This lecture introduces you to the Spring Framework. Spring framework is a lightweight container that implements the Dependency Injection design pattern. It allows you to focus on writing code as POJOs - plain old Java objects and manages the dependency between your objects for you. You will learn how to define your service by using the Spring configuration XML file.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Spring Framework,Java software programming:  Dependency Injection,Java software programming:  AOP
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.shortDescription: Introduction to Dependency Injection pattern
metadata.synopsis: Dependency Injection design pattern advocates the idea of decoupling the classes from each other. Any dependency between classes or modules is handled outside and the container injects the dependency. This allows building applications that are loosely coupled and can evolve over time.
metadata.description:
Dependency injection design pattern enables you to decouple your classes from each other. The basic problem as the software gets bigger and more complex is the dependencies between classes and modules. As the system grows, these become unmanageable. Any change to the system at this time requires a lot of struggle to find out all dependencies and update them. Similarly, such tight coupled systems are hard to maintain and test.

In order to decouple the systems, you work with Design By Contract - using Java Interfaces. The actual implementation of the interface is managed by Spring Framework. Therefore, as a caller class, you don't know which implementation is injected by Spring. This is the design pattern called Dependency Injection. Spring framework is one of the most popular implementations of the DI pattern
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Spring Framework,Java software programming:  Dependency Injection,Java software programming:  AOP,Java software programming:  Design Pattern
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Spring Framework,Java software programming:  Dependency Injection,Java software programming:  AOP,Java software programming:  Design Pattern

metadata.shortDescription: Spring MVC allows you to build web applications using the Module-View-Conroller design pattern.
metadata.synopsis: Spring MVC allows you to build web applications using the Module-View-Conroller design pattern.
metadata.description:
Spring MVC allows you to build web applications using the Module-View-Conroller design pattern. MVC design pattern decouples the data (model) from the logic of how it is presented (View) and the logic to control user actions on the data (Controller). This keeps the code simple, and easy to manage and allows large teams to work together with specialists working on each aspect of the application.

Spring MVC is a web application framework that (as you rightly guessed) allows you to build applications using the MVC design pattern. It provides you with standard ways to define your data model classes, decouples the views from your models and gives you a standard way to define the controller classes. Controller classes are main placeholder for all your logic and interaction with the back-end.

Pay close attention to the lectures as this is a very critical video for your project. What you learn from this lecture will be used in the next lecture to build your controller layer. Get in touch with your tutors if you do not understand these concepts fully.

metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.synopsis: Implement your sample controller using Spring MVC
metadata.description:

We will take the example of the Guestbook to learn how to implement the controller to save and retrieve messages from the database. We will also take a look at the Guestbook sample servlet that your first saw in the introduction to Google App Engine and compare the servlet code with your controller code.

When you compare the servlet with the controller code, the difference between the MVC controller and servlet based approach will become clear to you. While the servlet tries to do everything - business logic as well as rendering, the MVC's decoupling of model, view and controller is very simple and easy to work with.

metadata.shortDescription: Tutorial on Proxy design pattern
metadata.synopsis: Tutorial on Proxy design pattern
metadata.description: How does Spring framework work? If you don't understand this, you will not be able to appreciate it fully. You have heard of terms like dependency injection, AOP (Aspect Oriented Programming) and interceptors but how does it all work? The basic design pattern that makes Spring do its magic is the Proxy design pattern. When you define an interface, Spring creates a class - on the fly - that implements the same interface. This way, the class can do all the common work while delegating the actual call to the underlying implementation you had. Most of the magic done by Spring framework is achieved through such Proxy classes.

metadata.shortDescription: Learn how to test your application for bugs
metadata.synopsis: Learn how to test your application for bugs
metadata.description:
In this lesson, we will cover topics on how to test the web application's business logic. You want to make sure that the application is thoroughly tested and bug-free. Testing is an important part of any software development lifecycle. While there are dedicated teams for doing QA and testing the application, as a developer - UNIT TESTING is your responsibility.

Unit testing deals with testing individual units of code for correctness. This is what helps you to be sure that your code is bug-free when you release it for integration and testing. No software development task is complete unless you have unit tested it. This lesson will teach you basics on unit testing and you will extend your bookstore codebase to write the test cases.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Software Testing
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.shortDescription: Basic principles of unit testing
metadata.synopsis: Basic principles of unit testing
metadata.description:
As a programmer, you want to make sure that the code you write is bug-free. The simplest way to prove that is by testing the code with different types of inputs, and validating that it produces correct output. This is called unit testing and this lecture will introduce you to basic concepts in unit testing.

Unit testing is an important and integral part of your life as a developer. Every class or module that you write - you must test it by writing test cases to validate its correctness. These unit level tests are organized into test cases and test suites to organize and automate your testing.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Unit Testing,Java software programming:  JUNIT
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Unit Testing,Java software programming:  JUNIT

metadata.shortDescription: Unit testing in Java, using Junit framework
metadata.synopsis: Unit testing in Java, using Junit framework
metadata.description:
Now that you understand unit testing and its importance in your life as a programmer, lets talk about how you actually write the test cases. Ideally, you would want to write tests in such a way that you can pass different types of inputs to validate different scenarios. You should be able to then automate these tests so that you can simply run these every time you make any code changes and the tests should highlight any failures.

JUNIT is a framework in Java that gives you the above mentioned capabilities. You can write a suite of test cases, give different inputs to your programs and run assertions of different types to validate the output. You can integrate these tests automatically in your build process so that every time you compile your code, it is also tested. This lecture will introduce you to writing test cases using Junit.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  JUNIT,Java software programming:  Test Case
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  JUNIT,Java software programming:  Test Case

metadata.shortDescription: Unit testing also requires isolating parts of code.
metadata.synopsis: Unit testing also requires isolating parts of code.
metadata.description:
A simple question is - when you run your program to test it, should all its parts - including the database and the data inside it - be available? If that were the case, then setting up the tests to run would be a herculean task. Every time you make the build, you will end up spending significant amount of time to setup the environment and the database.

When you are testing your code, your focus is on the business logic that you wrote. Not on whether the JDBC driver can successfully load the data or not. Therefore, you should be able to isolate your code and test it, without any dependency on the underlying repository. You can't eliminate the dependency - but you can MOCK it. This lecture explains to you what mocking is, and how to use it to test your code.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  JUNIT,Java software programming:  Test Case,Java software programming:  Mock
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  JUNIT,Java software programming:  Test Case,Java software programming:  Mock

metadata.shortDescription: Different types of assertions in Junit
metadata.synopsis: Different types of assertions in Junit
metadata.description:
JUNIT supports many different types of asserts. Starting from simple asserts to check if the result is as expected (based on equals) or not (notEquals) or validating whether the condition is true or false (assertTrue, assertFalse). There are many more advanced types of assertions - such as checking if an exception is thrown under certain conditions.

This lecture introduces you to these different types of assertions and explains when to use which type. All asserts achieve the same underlying purpose - to validate that the output is as expected. Through this lecture you will understand the subtle differences between these different types of asserts.

metadata.shortDescription: Test driven development methodology
metadata.synopsis: Test driven development methodology
metadata.description:
When you start programming something new, how do you know when you are done? We all know the answer - when you have captured all the logic correctly and completed all aspects of the program. How do you put that into practice? Simple - by writing the test cases first. You write the test cases that cover all expected logic and conditions. When you start your implementation, there will be no logic, so all test cases will fail. Then, as you continue to code the specific conditions, those test cases will pass - until in the end all test cases pass. That is when you stop.

Follow these references to learn more about test driven development (TDD) or test-first development as a methodology. It is an important aspect of unit testing that will help you in writing good quality code.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  JUNIT,Java software programming:  Test Case,Java software programming:  Best Practices

metadata.shortDescription: Introduction to Object Oriented programming
metadata.synopsis: Introduction to Object Oriented programming
metadata.description:
If you are programming a Book store - how should you organize your classes so that the code is intuitive and simple to understand. For example, can a Book create itself? Can a publisher write the book? Questions like these help you understand and organize your code.

This is called Object Orientation - or Object Oriented Programming. You organize your code into classes that represent objects with behavior. Then you allocate responsibilities (methods and business logic) to these classes as it is intuitive. Rather than simply using your intuition, you can apply the 4 basic principles of Object Oriented programming. This lesson will introduce you to Object Oriented programming by taking a few examples and illustrating the concepts.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Object Oriented Design
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.shortDescription: Basic principles of object oriented programming
metadata.synopsis: Basic principles of object oriented programming
metadata.description:
You pick any book on Java or Object Oriented Programming - and it will talk about the 4 basic principles of OO - Abstraction, Polymorphism, Inheritance and Encapsulation. But what do these really mean? Unless you understand these principles beyond the superficial explanation, you will not be able to connect with OO concepts.

In this lecture, we will take some examples to illustrate the principles. Instead of taking the principle and explaining, we will first take a look at examples and how these are modeled. As we go through the process, the basic principles will emerge.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Object Oriented Design,Java software programming:  Class,Java software programming:  Inheritance,Java software programming:  Encapsulation
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Object Oriented Design,Java software programming:  Class,Java software programming:  Inheritance,Java software programming:  Encapsulation

metadata.shortDescription: Modeling different kinds of books for your project
metadata.synopsis: Modeling different kinds of books for your project
metadata.description:
Let us put what you learnt to practice. In your project, you have different types of books such as Novels, Magazenes, Newsletters etc. Question is - how do you model these in your classes so that you can capture the behavior.

In this lecture you will learn how to design different types of classes by learning about Inheritance. You will learn how to define base classes, extend these and define child classes.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Object Oriented Design,Java software programming:  Class,Java software programming:  Generalization
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Object Oriented Design,Java software programming:  Class,Java software programming:  Generalization

metadata.shortDescription: Overloading and overriding methods
metadata.synopsis: Overloading and overriding methods
metadata.description:
When you applied the inheritance principle, you got a hierarchy of classes. The base classes capture business logic that is more generic, while child classes specialize this logic to make it more specific/concrete. They do that by overriding the behavior of the methods in base classes. Simplest example is the EQUALS method that has a default implementation in the root class - Object. In your child classes you can override the equals method to write your custom logic.

So far so good, but then what is overloading? This lecture will introduce these two seemingly similar concepts and what is the difference between them. You will learn how to recognize overloading and overriding scenarios and make decisions on when you need overloading v/s overriding.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Subclass,Java software programming:  Generalization
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Subclass,Java software programming:  Generalization

metadata.shortDescription: How do you save inheritance hierarchy?
metadata.synopsis: How do you save inheritance hierarchy?
metadata.description:
Great - now you've got different types of books defined by using a class hierarchy. Next question is - how do you map this to the database tables? Should all types of books (whether these are novels or magazenes) be stored in the same table? Or should they be separate tables? How do you do this with your ORM framework Hibernate?

This lecture takes you through the process of mapping the different classes in an inheritance hierarchy to the database. You will learn about different ways in which such hierarchies are persisted and how to model the persistence using Hibernate.

metadata.shortDescription: Handy tips and guidelines for designing your classes
metadata.synopsis: Handy tips and guidelines for designing your classes
metadata.description:
Lets say you have two classes and you want to allocate a particular method to one of the classes - which class is the right place to contain that business logic? You can think of classes as people who are Lazy. Each class should resist the additional responsibility as best as it can. In the end, the class where the functionality naturally belongs will lose the argument.

This is called the Laziness Principle. This tutorial takes you through some handy rules like this which will help you in designing your classes and allocating responsibilities to these classes.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Object Oriented Design
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Object Oriented Design

metadata.shortDescription: Design the repository layer for your application.
metadata.synopsis: Design the repository layer for your application.
metadata.description:
In this lesson, you will design the repository layer for your book store. The repository layer gets data from the database and returns it to the controller. You have already seen that code in action. Now, lets explore the concepts behind this. Why do we call it a "LAYER"? And what are the responsibilities of this layer? Why do we propose that the layer should have an interface?

By the end of this lesson, you will enhance your book store project and combine the hibernate code you wrote with the controller to make a full web application. So gear up for the ride - it is going to be an exciting lesson.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Repository,Java software programming:  ORM
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.shortDescription: Introduction to the layered web applications
metadata.synopsis: Introduction to the layered web applications
metadata.description:
You will come across this term LAYER many times. What is the meaning of a layer? Take the TCP/IP stack for example. Each layer is responsible for a specific type of functions. The stack will not work even if any one of the layers is not available. Similarly, web applications can be broken down into logical layers. Each layer is allocated a certain responsibility - such as interacting with the database, or handling the web requests.

In this lecture, you will understand the different types of layers in a web application, and how to determine which functionality goes where. You will learn how the layers interact with each other to serve a request.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Web Application Development,Java software programming:  Layered Architecture
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Web Application Development,Java software programming:  Layered Architecture

metadata.shortDescription: Design by contract - using Java interfaces
metadata.synopsis: Design by contract - using Java interfaces
metadata.description:
We touched upon this topic earlier. When you have different parties interacting with each other, they need a common interface or a contract that both parties should abide by. For example, when we talk about a repository layer in the web application, the method to load all books is a contract. Repository implementation must do whatever is necessary to return the list of books to the caller.

Different implementations may realize the contract in different ways. For example, a mock repository that you saw, returns a hard-coded list of sample books. Whereas the actual implementation of Hibernate based repository returns all books that are there in the database. This lecture explains the concept and principles behind this.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Interface,Java software programming:  Design By Contract
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Interface,Java software programming:  Design By Contract

metadata.shortDescription: Generics in Java - reuse code
metadata.synopsis: Generics in Java - reuse code
metadata.description:
You have seen the angular brackets - for example most of the java.utils classes have this (e.g. List). You probably also understand that it means a list of integers. But what exactly does it indicate? And why do we need this additional complexity?

This lecture will explain this concept by talking about the need for type-safety in Java and how generics allows you to write reusable code while ensuring runtime type-safety. This is a very important concept in going beyond simple Java programming - so pay attention. If you have doubts at the end of the lecture, join the Tutoring Webinar that is scheduled at the end of this lecture.

metadata.shortDescription: Spring annotations used in different layers
metadata.synopsis: Spring annotations used in different layers
metadata.description:
This lecture discusses the different annotations that are part of the Spring framework that indicate classes at different layers. For example, @Controller, @Service and @Repository annotations are all marker annotations for the different layers.

In addition to the marker annotations for layers, we will also take a look at the different annotations that are relevant within each layer. Put it the other way - if you see a class with @Entity annotation - which layer does it belong to? This lecture will help you understand the code structuring better.

metadata.shortDescription: Do generics work with older code?
metadata.synopsis: Do generics work with older code?
metadata.description:
You can see that the java.utils classes have introduced generics and type-safety. This was done in the JDK1.5 onwards. Does the code written and compiled earlier will still work with the new utils packages?

To understand the answer, you need to know a little bit about how generics actually works. Java works with the concept of "Type Erasure". Generics are only there for compile time type-safety checking. This tutorial will explain the concept and answer the question above.

metadata.description:
When you display an existing book, allowing users to edit it - your code In UI will consist of 2 parts. First is a query to get the data and display it on screen. Second is to take the form data and construct a request to send to the server. There is a lot of boiler plate code that you need to write to do this work and this pattern repeats on most form/data-entry type pages.

The MVVM design pattern works with the same principle, simplifying the code needed to achieve this objective by enabling two-way binding. Two-way binding refers to the UI refreshing the JSON data and changes to JSON data refreshing the UI automatically. This tutorial gives you an explanation and a sample of two-way binding.

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Quality Engineering,Java software programming:  Performance Engineering
metadata.description:
What happens when you launch your website? How many users will be able to access it? What would happen if every internet user in the world accesses your application at the same time? Will your site be able to handle this kind of load?

To answer these questions, you must understand about performance of software systems. Response time, and Throughput of the application are two different aspects of performance. How do we measure performance? This lesson will take you through this journey and talk about common techniques and patterns that you can use to improve performance and throughput of your applications.
metadata.synopsis: Load testing and validating the performance of your application
metadata.shortDescription: Load testing and validating the performance of your application
Techniques and patterns for measuring the performance of your web application
metadata.synopsis: Techniques and patterns for measuring the performance of your web application
metadata.description:
How do you feel if the website you are browsing takes forever to load? Frustrating right? Chances are - you wont probably revisit the website unless absolutely necessary. Another familiar example is the IRCTC - which works well most of the time, except in the morning when the number of users is very high.

We are talking about the performance of the website. These are the two different aspects of performance - response time and throughput. This lecture explains to you the fundamental concepts of performance and how you can measure it for your web application.

metadata.shortDescription: Techniques and patterns for improving the performance of your web application
metadata.synopsis: Techniques to improve the response time of your application
metadata.description:
Response time of the application is affected by many different aspects in design and code. To improve the response time, you need to optimize your code, build indices on your data, and avoid unnecesary iterations, loops and reduce the number of database queries.

This lecture introduces you to these concepts, so that you can look for possible issues and learn how to optimize the performance of your code. Understanding these will set you apart from the crowd at workspace.

metadata.shortDescription: Techniques and patterns for improving the throughput of your web application
metadata.synopsis: Techniques and patterns for improving the throughput of your web application
metadata.description:
The problem with IRCTC is that in the morning the number of users accessing the website is too high - more than what it can handle. As a result, many of the operations do not function correctly. This is the issue with the throughput of the website. Throughput problems come due to capacity of the infrastructure, as well as issues in code such as database locks, incorrect thread synchronization etc.

This lecture introduces you to the common problems that will limit the number of users your website can handle, and how to optimize or refactor your code to improve the throughput.

metadata.synopsis: Learn how to measure the response time of your web application across different layers
metadata.description: Measuring the repsonse time is not just done at Jmeter layer. If that was the case, you would get the total response time, however you will not be able to investigate and debug a possible issue in the controller or repository layer. To do this, you must measure the response time at these individual layers. This tutorial introduces you to various techniques to measure the software performance in controller and repository. This information can help you tune these layers of your web application.
metadata.keyword: ,Java software programming:  Performance Engineering, Java software programming:  Response Time, Java software programming:  Optimization
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: ,Java software programming:  Performance Engineering, Java software programming:  Response Time, Java software programming:  Optimization

metadata.shortDescription: Learn how to record a complex JMETER test
metadata.synopsis: Learn how to record a complex JMETER test
metadata.description:
You saw the simplest Jmeter test case - sending an HTTP request and measuring the response. However, most real world users would follow certain patterns when accessing the website. For example, typical usage is that the users log in, go to the browse page, search for a few terms, see some details of books before checking out. This is a complex set of requests and responses between the client and the server.

Such complex requests are best captured by using the Jmeter's recording facility. This tutorial will explain the process of setting up Jmeter as a proxy and then using it to record an interaction with the web application.
metadata.keyword: ,Java software programming:  Performance Engineering, Java software programming:  Load Testing, Java software programming:  JMETER
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: ,Java software programming:  Performance Engineering, Java software programming:  Load Testing, Java software programming:  JMETER

metadata.shortDescription: Analyze the results description
metadata.synopsis: Analyze the results description
metadata.description:
Wasn't that an interesting experience? Running a load test on your application by simulating hundreds of users accessing your book store? You now have captured a lot of interesting data about your application's performance under this kind of load. The question now is - is it good or bad? How do you interpret the results from a performance engineering exercise like this?

This lesson will explain how you analyze and make sense out of the performance data that you have collected for your application.
metadata.keyword: ,Java software programming:  Performance Engineering, Java software programming:  Load Testing, Java software programming:  JMETER
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.synopsis: Exercise: Load test your book store and optimize performance
metadata.description: Exercise: Load test your book store and optimize performance. Record a jmeter script for the scenario described above and run the load test on your application. Analyze the results and optimize the business logic, operations and the responses your code is returning. Submit the Jmeter script, and the code changes and a write-up on the approach you took for optimizing the application.

metadata.description:
We will summarize the learnings so far, and do a recap of the important points that we discussed. At the end of the course, we will discuss the areas where you can further explore.

There is no end to the learning and the technology space is continuously evoling. Throughout the course, we practiced how to explore, access the forums to find solutions to your problems etc. We will part with tips and tricks related to such interactions on the web.

You will learn the best practices, conventions and other recommendations that are important for developing good quality software applications such as continuous integration. refactoring the code and the intricacies of refactoring.

The content for this module will be uploaded in the next few weeks
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Best Practices
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.shortDescription: Learn the best practices related to coding, testing, quality and processes in the industry
metadata.synopsis: Learn the best practices related to coding, testing, quality and processes in the industry
metadata.description:
Our exciting journey is coming to an end. In the last few weeks, you have learnt important skills that you would need to work in a large team on real projects. But this is not the end of your learning. There is a lot more to learn as you have undoubtedly seen in various references for exploratory content. Remember that always.

As you step into your next adventure in the industry, you need to arm yourself with some of the best practices that will set you apart from the ordinary. For example, if you write messy code you may still get it to work as expected, but over time you will find yourself spending a lot of time maintaining, enhancing and cleaning it. Instead, if you write clean, readable code, you will improve your own productivity and will be able to work with others easily. In this lesson, this and some of the other recommended practices are presented that will help you become more effective and excel at your job.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Best Practices
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.shortDescription: Best practices on code quality, writing clean and readable code, and following coding standards
metadata.synopsis: Best practices on code quality, writing clean and readable code, and following coding standards
metadata.description: Writing good quality code is an art. Martin Fowler has said - "Anyone can write code that a computer can understand. Good programmers write code that humans can understand". This is the essence of writing good code. This lecture introduces you to the best practices, and tips of how you can write good code that others can read and understand.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Quality Engineering, Java software programming:  Coding Standard
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Quality Engineering,Java software programming:  Coding Standard

metadata.shortDescription: Learn refactoring - the art of improving your code
metadata.synopsis: Learn refactoring - the art of improving your code
metadata.description: When you see an inefficient for loop - you fix it. When you see an incorrect class hierarchy, you change it to make it correct. These are examples of refactoring your code for efficiency, or correctness. In general, you would address these aspects in your code that relate to code quality, maintainability, efficiency, performance etc. This lecture introduces you to the techniques and patterns for refactoring. It explains how you can recognize an opportunity for refactoring and what you can do to fix it.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Refactoring, Java software programming:  Design Pattern
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Refactoring,Java software programming:  Design Pattern

metadata.shortDescription: Learn about continuous integration when working on large projects with large teams
metadata.synopsis: Learn about continuous integration when working on large projects with large teams
metadata.description:
When you work on large projects in large teams, the builds and integration becomes a big problem. Successful projects integrate and test continuously by using various CI tools like Jenkins or SonarQube. These tools run every night and build the latest version of the code from your source control repository, run the automated unit tests and checkers for code quality. This process gives you a handle on the project every day. Any commits that break the build are highlighted, similarly, test cases that fail cause the build to fail.

This is an important aspect of the process that you need to understand. This lecture familiarizes you with the CI process and walks you through the Jenkins sample build configuration.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Continuous Integration, Java software programming:  Nightly Builds
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Continuous Integration,Java software programming:  Nightly Builds

metadata.shortDescription: Concluding the journey with a quick recap and how you can go from here to next steps
metadata.synopsis: Concluding the journey with a quick recap and how you can go from here to next steps
metadata.description:
Final stop of our journey. Remember what I said earlier - learning is lifelong. Technology space is continuously evolving. The frameworks you learnt today will evolve, new frameworks and technologies will come around. You must continue to make an endeavor to learn new things, explore and apply them in your work.

This lesson will leave you with pointers on further areas to explore and learn, particularly in cloud computing, multi-tenant systems and working with Google App Engine

Someone once said - "teach a man how to fish and you feed him for life" - happy fishing

metadata.shortDescription: Recap of the concepts that you have learnt in this course - from the basics of cloud computing, to building your own e-commerce application
metadata.synopsis: Recap of the concepts that you have learnt in this course - from the basics of cloud computing, to building your own e-commerce application
metadata.description:
This has been an exciting journey for me. Thanks for completing the course. This would not have been possible without your commitment and perseverance.

Starting from the basic introduction to cloud computing and Google Appengine, you have learnt a great deal about how the web applications are built and hosted. You learnt both - local webapps running in Tomcat, as well as the webapp built and deployed on Google Appengine. You have learnt about the layers in the application, and how these are integrated while working with interfaces and design by contract.

Frameworks that you learnt - Spring, Spring MVC, Hibernate and jQuery will go a long way with you. We have only covered these at a very high level. Do explore further and go into more details as this will be useful for you throughout your career.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming: Java Web Application Development
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming: Java Web Application Development

metadata.shortDescription: This is not the end of your learning. The specific topics you should pursue further.
metadata.synopsis: This is not the end of your learning. The specific topics you should pursue further.
metadata.description:
In particular, you should pursue the frameworks further (jQuery, Hibernate, Spring). Each framework has a lot of interesting and powerful features that you can learn to utilize. The other important area of further learning for you is CSS and the possibilities that it gives you for building rich, engaging user experiences.

In addition, there are a whole set of JavaScript libraries and frameworks that you should familiarize yourself with. In this course we did not cover any of these - but frameworks like Bootstrap, AngularJS and Handlebars are all very important frameworks that you will find in most of the web projects these days. These are good areas to explore and learn further.

metadata.shortDescription: A discussion on multi-tenancy and governance when building cloud based applications.
metadata.synopsis: A discussion on multi-tenancy and governance when building cloud based applications.
metadata.description: Cloud computing models have many interesting models for offering your application. From simply a place to host your application, to offering it as a service (SaaS) to your customers. The multi-tenancy models related to SaaS services have interesting challenges such as ensuring all tenants get equal share of system's resources. This lecture touches upon these aspects of cloud computing.
metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Cloud Computing, Java software programming:  Governance
metadata.author: Feroz Sheikh

metadata.keyword: Java software programming:  Cloud Computing,Java software programming:  Governance

metadata.shortDescription: More on Google Appengine - what more you have that you can focus on and learn
metadata.synopsis: More on Google Appengine - what more you have that you can focus on and learn
metadata.description: In this course, we looked at Google Appengine, but the focus was primarily on Java programming. We only leveraged the authentication service and the data store provided by Google Appengine. In addition to these, it offers many other services - such as Image Processing, Caching, Mail, BigTable storage, MapReduce etc. This final lecture talks a bit about these services and where in future you may encounter these. This is a good parting point for us - you can continue your journey with cloud computing on these areas.
